This gave Reuchlin an opportunity of making further pro- gress in his favourite study under the guidance of Qbadyah Sforno of Cesena. On his return from Italy Reuchlin* betook himself once more to Stuttgart, where the third duke, Ulrich, was still a minor, and in 1502 he attained his highest judicial rank as a Judge of the Swabian League.

The year 1506 saw the publication of Reuchlin⁷s De Badium-ntis Hebraicis, an elementary Hebrew grammar—largely derived from a work by the rabbi, David Kimchi, quoted by Boswell—-but displaying wide reading, and destined to have a powerful effect in attracting the attention of scholars to Semitic studies.

The necessary limitations of this Introduction do not permit of reference to Reuchlin's many other literary labours in the field of pure scholarship.
